title.narrative: PROTECTION AND HUMANITARIAN ACTION

description.narrative: By September 2015, children, adolescents, families, communities and institutions in the areas most affected by the armed conflict, have increased their capacity to protect children and adolescents the direct victims will have received comprehensive care as part of the national and international legislation.

sector.narrative: Administrative data and Information Management System (IMS) including CPIMS+, GBVIMS+, MRMIMS+

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By September 2015, children, adolescents, families, communities and institutions in the areas most affected by the armed conflict, have increased their capacity to protect children and adolescents; the direct victims will have received comprehensive care as part of the national and international legislation.
Number of institutions of the national government that monitor the implementation of the Report of the General Secretarys recommendations .

baseline.value: 2 institutions, the Foreign Ministry and the Technical Secretariat of the Intersectoral Commission for the Prevention of Recruitment are following up the recommendations.

target.value: 2014:By December 2014, 9 institutions monitor the implementation of the recommendations (ICBF, PGN, FGN, Forensic Medicine, Ministry of Defense, MEN, Victims Unit, Foreign Ministry and Technical Secretaria

actual.value: 2015:Achieved. Meetings have been held with 8 institutions (Ministry of Education, ICBF - 2 meetings, Victims Unit, National Planning Department, Office of the Prosecutor General of the Nation, Ministry of Defense - 2 meetings and the Intersectoral Commission for the Prevention of Recruitment) in which t

title.narrative: % of new civilian victims of APL / UXO / IED, who know their rights and the route to access to integral attention services.

baseline.value: Between 2010 there were 80 new civilian victims in the country. Of these, 32 victims suffered accidents in the 9 departments prioritized by UNICEF. UNICEF attended the 32 new victims (100%) (plus 77 old victims identified). The 32 victims attended represented 40% of new victims nationwide in 2010.

title.narrative: Number of local humanitarian teams with capacity to report cases around the six violations referred to in Resolution 1612

baseline.value: By December 2013, 6 HLT (in as many departments: Antioquia, Choco, Arauca, Cordoba, Cauca and Nario)

target.value: 2014:By December 2014, 8 HLT (in as many departments: Antioquia, Choco, Arauca, Cordoba, Cauca, Nariño, Putumayo, Valle del Cauca)

actual.value: 2015:9 local humanitarian teams have been formed or strengthened (Antioquia, Arauca, Cauca-Valle del Cauca, Chocó, Córdoba, Meta, Nariño, Norte de Santander and Putumayo). In 3 cases (Antioquia, Chocó and Putumayo) the LHTs have chosen to work on the subject of children and armed conflict through the TGP

title.narrative: Percentage of children aged between 12 and 17 years, of 58 priority municipalities in 10 departments, participating for the first time and for at least two years in processes of building protection environments that protect them of becoming victims of recruitment by illegal armed groups and criminal bands., in the framework of the National Policy on the Prevention of Recruitment and the Use of Children for the armed conflict.

baseline.value: During 2012, in priority municipalities, inhabiting 366,466 children and adolescents between 12 and 17 years (Source: Municipal Population Projections. Department of Statistics, DANE)

title.narrative: % of required documents submitted on time to the UN Special Representative of the Secretary General on Children and Armed Conflict on the situation of the violation of children rights in the conflict in Colombia

baseline.value: During 2013, inputs for 4 Global Horizontal Notes and for the Secretary General Annual Report on children and armed conflict were send completed and on time.

target.value: 2014:By December 2014, 100% of inputs for 4 Global Horizontal Notes and for the Secrreary General Annual Report on Children and Armed Copnflict were send completed and on time.

actual.value: 2015:Up to September 2015, 100% of documents required by the Special Representative of the Secretary General on Children and Armed Conflict have been submitted on time.

title.narrative: Number of municipalities where the strategy Promotion of Rights of children and adolescents and prevention of their victimization by organized groups acting outside the law , is implemented through Integral Psychosocial Attention Units

baseline.value: For 2011, the ICBF focused 26 municipalities for intervention.

title.narrative: Number of departments where the programme Hogar Gestor is implemented with a gender focus.

baseline.value: For 2011, the ICBF had not designed or included a gender approach in the Program of attention of demobilized children from illegal armed groups and criminal bands. Baseline: 0

title.narrative: Number of municipalities in the departments of Antioquia, Choc, Meta and Nario who design, included in the Development Plan, allocate resources and implement action plans for the Prevention of Recruitment

baseline.value: For 2012, the Intersectoral Commission of Prevention of recruitment has focused 114 municipalities in 30 departments, and six locations in the city of Bogot DC

title.narrative: Number of persons able to prevent accidents with Antipersonnel Landmines (APL), and Unexploded Ordnance (UXO) and Improvised Explosive Device (IED)

baseline.value: In 2010, 21,000 people in 18 municipalities (community leaders, children, educators and parents) have acquired knowledge about safe behavior with respect to APL, UXO and IED. (16% of the total rural population in the 18 municipalities)

title.narrative: Number of departments that have implemented the National Policy on Mine Integral Action

baseline.value: In 2010, four priority departments began to strength their capacities in AICMA

title.narrative: Number of officers and soldiers who enter the BITER that have been sensitized by the direct participants of the training processes in HR and IHL, with emphasis on children.

baseline.value: In 2011, 179,832 officers and soldiers of the Armed Forces of Colombia participated in training processes on operational, militar and human rights issues in the 26 Training Battalions (BITER) of the country.

title.narrative: Number of global notes produced in 2012 notes bimonthly, inputs and revisions to the CAR II, inputs for the Global Report 2012

baseline.value: Recommendations issued by the Secretary General. Conclusions reached by the Working Group on Children and Armed Conflict Security Council

target.value: 2013:By 2013, six (6) annual global notes, a national report and contributions to the annual global report.

actual.value: 2015:By September 2015, all global horizontal notes (1 every quarter), and the inputs the country annual report and the global annual report have been send completed and on time.
